title: Republican Dan Bishop Wins North Carolina Congressional Seat With Trump’s Support
text:
CHARLOTTE, N.C.—Voters in a conservative congressional district picked President Trump ally Republican Dan Bishop in Tuesday’s special election instead of a Democrat who had promised to seek compromise in Washington.

Mr. Bishop, a 55-year-old state senator who campaigned on a promise to be in lockstep with Mr. Trump, defeated Democrat Dan McCready in the Ninth Congressional District based in the suburbs of Charlotte.

In his victory speech, Mr. Bishop said he would go to Washington to protect the border, fight Democrats in the House and support the Trump agenda. “Under this president, America is great again,” he said.

Mr. McCready, a 36-year-old veteran and entrepreneur, had campaigned as a centrist, emphasizing his service as a Marine in the Iraq war and pledging to put country over party.

Mr. McCready said late Tuesday he was proud that the campaign came so close to carrying a reliably Republican district. “We may not have won this campaign, but that does not mean that we were wrong,” he said. “As long as there are people who thrive off our division, there is still work to be done,” he said.

The GOP victory in the rare do-over election was a boon to Mr. Trump, who tweeted his support repeatedly for Mr. Bishop and campaigned for him Monday in Fayetteville, a military town at the far eastern edges of the district. Vice President Mike Pence came to the state for Mr. Bishop on Monday in Union County, a GOP stronghold. Mr. Trump won the district by 12 percentage points in 2016.

Tuesday’s vote was seen as a test of how voters, particularly suburbanites who make up much of the district, view Mr. Trump as the 2020 campaign kicks into gear, people from both political parties said in interviews.

Mr. Trump took credit late Tuesday for Mr. Bishop’s success, tweeting that “Dan Bishop was down 17 points 3 weeks ago. He then asked me for help, we changed his strategy together, and he ran a great race.”

The Ninth District stretches from the Charlotte suburbs and neighboring Union County three hours’ drive east through several rural counties. Roughly 60% of registered voters live in the Charlotte suburbs, a rapidly urbanizing area that had long been GOP territory.

The race was unusually close for a district that has been a Republican stronghold for many years, with analysts saying Mr. Trump was the reason the district was in play in the first place.

David Wasserman of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report said it was the rural areas that guaranteed Mr. Bishop’s win, not the suburbs, and tweeted that Mr. Bishop’s narrow margin was “still bad news for the House GOP overall.”

President Trump gave his support to state Sen. Dan Bishop at a rally in Fayetteville, N.C., on Monday. Photo: Chris Seward/Associated Press

Outside a suburban Charlotte polling place Tuesday, Wendy Hawthorne, a 43-year-old who works for a family business, said she voted for Mr. Bishop because she likes how well the economy is doing and she supports the Trump agenda, if not the man. She said she didn’t contemplate voting for a Democrat because she opposes the agenda of the progressive wing that seems to be driving the party.

She said she talks about politics with her closest friends but few others in the wealthy suburbs where she lives, which are rapidly changing with newcomers from other parts of the country. “It’s hard to talk with people,” she said. “It’s not worth it. People get so upset.”

Outside groups spent a near-record amount for a single special election, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Groups such as the national parties’ congressional committees spent $6.8 million to boost the Republican, and about $3.9 million to help the Democrat.

In the initial election last fall, then-GOP nominee Mark Harris beat Mr. McCready by fewer than 1,000 votes. But state election officials invalidated the results after it emerged that a consultant for Mr. Harris had improperly handled absentee ballots.
